short_description: A timeless Neapolitan masterpiece featuring a pillowy crust, vibrant San Marzano tomato sauce, creamy fresh mozzarella, and fragrant basil leaves. This iconic pizza represents the colors of the Italian flag and delivers pure Mediterranean simplicity at its finest.
steps: Dissolve the yeast in lukewarm water and let it activate for 5 minutes until slightly foamy.
In a large bowl, combine the flour and salt, then gradually add the yeast water while mixing.
Knead the dough on a floured surface for 10 minutes until smooth and elastic.
Place the dough in an oiled bowl, cover with a damp cloth, and let rise for 2 hours until doubled.
Preheat your oven to the highest setting (250°°C/480°°F) with a pizza stone or baking sheet inside.
Divide the dough into 4 portions and stretch each into a thin round, leaving edges slightly thicker.
Spread a thin layer of tomato sauce, leaving a 1-inch border for the crust.
Tear the mozzarella into pieces and distribute evenly over the sauce.
Bake for 8-10 minutes until the crust is golden and cheese is bubbling.
Remove from oven, top with fresh basil leaves, drizzle with olive oil, and serve immediately.
cooking_tips: For best results, let the dough cold-ferment in the refrigerator overnight for deeper flavor.
Use a pizza stone preheated for at least 30 minutes to achieve a crispy bottom.
Less is more with toppings - overloading will result in a soggy center.
nutrition_benefits: This pizza provides a good balance of carbohydrates for energy, protein from the mozzarella cheese, and lycopene from the tomatoes which is a powerful antioxidant. The olive oil adds heart-healthy monounsaturated fats. Fresh basil contains vitamins K, A, and C, plus essential oils with anti-inflammatory properties.

short_description: An authentic Roman treasure featuring al dente spaghetti coated in a luxuriously silky sauce of eggs, aged Pecorino Romano, crispy guanciale, and freshly cracked black pepper. This dish showcases Italian cuisine's genius for transforming simple ingredients into extraordinary flavors.
steps: Bring a large pot of generously salted water to a rolling boil.
Cut the guanciale into small strips or cubes, about 1cm thick.
In a bowl, whisk together the egg yolks, whole eggs, and finely grated Pecorino Romano until smooth.
Add generous amounts of freshly ground black pepper to the egg mixture and set aside.
Cook the guanciale in a large cold pan over medium heat, letting the fat render slowly for 8-10 minutes until crispy.
Cook the spaghetti until al dente, reserving 1 cup of pasta water before draining.
Remove the guanciale pan from heat and let it cool for 1 minute.
Add the hot drained pasta to the guanciale pan and toss to coat in the rendered fat.
Working quickly off the heat, pour the egg mixture over the pasta while tossing continuously.
Add small splashes of pasta water while tossing to create a creamy, glossy sauce.
Serve immediately with extra Pecorino and black pepper on top.
cooking_tips: Never add the egg mixture to a hot pan on the heat, or you will get scrambled eggs instead of a silky sauce.
The residual heat from the pasta and pan is what gently cooks the eggs into a creamy coating.
Authentic carbonara never includes cream, garlic, or onions.
nutrition_benefits: Carbonara is an excellent source of complete protein from eggs and cheese, providing all essential amino acids. The eggs contain choline, vital for brain health, and the Pecorino Romano offers calcium for bone strength. The dish provides sustained energy from complex carbohydrates in the pasta.

short_description: Layers of silky pasta sheets, rich meat ragu, creamy bechamel, and melted Parmigiano. This iconic dish from Bologna represents Italian comfort food at its finest.
steps: Finely chop onion, carrot, and celery for soffritto.
Brown meats with soffritto, add wine, then tomato passata.
Simmer ragu for at least 2 hours until rich and thick.
Make bechamel: melt butter, whisk in flour, gradually add warm milk.
Cook bechamel until thick, add nutmeg and half the Parmigiano.
Cook lasagna sheets if using fresh, or use no-boil sheets.
Layer: bechamel, pasta, ragu, bechamel, Parmigiano. Repeat.
Finish with bechamel and plenty of Parmigiano on top.
Bake at 375°F for 40-45 minutes until golden and bubbling.
Rest 15 minutes before serving.
cooking_tips: A slow-cooked ragu is the key to exceptional lasagna.
The bechamel should be thick enough to coat a spoon.
Let the lasagna rest before cutting for clean slices.
nutrition_benefits: Lasagna provides complete protein from meat and dairy. The dish offers calcium from cheese and milk. Tomatoes add lycopene, a powerful antioxidant.

short_description: Creamy saffron-infused rice that is the pride of Milan. This golden dish showcases the Italian technique of slowly building flavor through patient stirring.
steps: Steep saffron in 1/4 cup warm stock for 10 minutes.
Heat remaining stock and keep warm.
Saute finely diced onion in half the butter until soft.
Add rice and toast for 2 minutes until edges are translucent.
Add wine and stir until absorbed.
Add warm stock one ladle at a time, stirring constantly.
When almost done, stir in saffron with its liquid.
Continue until rice is creamy and al dente, about 18 minutes.
Remove from heat, add remaining butter and Parmigiano.
Cover and rest 2 minutes before serving.
cooking_tips: The stock must be warm to maintain cooking temperature.
Constant stirring releases starch for creamy texture.
The final mantecatura (adding butter and cheese) is essential.
nutrition_benefits: Risotto provides complex carbohydrates for sustained energy. Saffron contains antioxidants and may improve mood. Parmigiano adds calcium and protein.

short_description: Braised veal shanks in a rich wine and vegetable sauce, finished with bright gremolata. This Milanese specialty is traditionally served with saffron risotto.
steps: Tie string around veal shanks to keep meat attached to bone.
Dredge shanks in flour and brown in butter on all sides.
Remove meat, add diced vegetables and cook until soft.
Return meat to pot, add wine and reduce by half.
Add stock and tomatoes, bring to a simmer.
Cover and braise in 325°F oven for 2-2.5 hours until very tender.
Make gremolata by mixing lemon zest, minced garlic, and parsley.
Carefully transfer shanks to serving plates.
Reduce sauce if needed and spoon over meat.
Top with gremolata and serve immediately.
cooking_tips: The marrow inside the bone is a delicacy - provide small spoons.
Low and slow braising is key to tender meat.
Gremolata should be added at the last minute for freshness.
nutrition_benefits: Ossobuco provides high-quality protein and iron from veal. Bone marrow offers healthy fats and collagen. The gremolata adds vitamin C and antioxidants.

short_description: Layers of espresso-soaked ladyfingers and silky mascarpone cream, dusted with cocoa. This beloved Italian dessert from the Veneto region is a perfect ending to any meal.
steps: Separate egg yolks and whites.
Whisk yolks with sugar until pale and fluffy.
Add mascarpone and mix until smooth.
Beat egg whites to stiff peaks and fold into mascarpone mixture.
Mix espresso with Marsala or rum.
Quickly dip each ladyfinger in espresso - don't soak too long.
Layer soaked ladyfingers in a dish.
Spread half the mascarpone cream over ladyfingers.
Repeat layers, ending with cream.
Refrigerate at least 4 hours or overnight. Dust with cocoa before serving.
cooking_tips: Use room temperature mascarpone for easier mixing.
The ladyfingers should be moist but not soggy.
Tiramisu is best made a day ahead for flavors to meld.
nutrition_benefits: Tiramisu provides protein from eggs and cheese. Mascarpone offers calcium and vitamin A. Coffee contains antioxidants and may boost metabolism.

short_description: Fresh basil pounded with pine nuts, garlic, Parmigiano, and olive oil into a vibrant green sauce. This Ligurian classic transforms simple pasta into a celebration of summer.
steps: Toast pine nuts lightly in a dry pan.
In a mortar, crush garlic with coarse salt.
Add pine nuts and pound to a paste.
Add basil leaves a handful at a time, grinding against the sides.
Add grated cheeses and mix well.
Slowly drizzle in olive oil while stirring.
Cook pasta in well-salted water.
Reserve 1/2 cup pasta water before draining.
Loosen pesto with some pasta water.
Toss pasta with pesto and serve immediately.
cooking_tips: A mortar and pestle yields the best texture, but a food processor works.
Don't over-process or basil will oxidize and turn dark.
Pasta water helps the pesto coat the pasta evenly.
nutrition_benefits: Pesto is rich in heart-healthy olive oil and antioxidants from basil. Pine nuts provide protein and minerals. The cheeses add calcium and protein.

short_description: Grilled bread rubbed with garlic and topped with ripe tomatoes, fresh basil, and olive oil. This simple Tuscan appetizer celebrates the quality of Italian ingredients.
steps: Dice tomatoes and place in a bowl.
Add torn basil, olive oil, balsamic, salt, and pepper.
Let marinate for 15-30 minutes.
Slice bread into 1/2 inch thick slices.
Grill or toast bread until golden with char marks.
While still hot, rub one side of each slice with cut garlic.
Drizzle with a little olive oil.
Top with tomato mixture just before serving.
Serve immediately while bread is still warm and crispy.
cooking_tips: Use the ripest, most flavorful tomatoes you can find.
The bread must be served immediately - it goes soggy quickly.
Quality olive oil makes all the difference.
nutrition_benefits: Bruschetta provides lycopene from tomatoes. Olive oil offers heart-healthy monounsaturated fats. Garlic has natural antimicrobial properties.

short_description: A hearty vegetable soup that varies by season and region. This Italian classic features beans, pasta, and whatever vegetables are freshest, simmered into a nourishing meal.
steps: Dice all vegetables into similar-sized pieces.
Saute onion, carrot, and celery in olive oil until soft.
Add remaining vegetables except zucchini.
Add tomatoes, stock, and Parmigiano rind.
Simmer for 30 minutes until vegetables are almost tender.
Add zucchini, beans, and pasta.
Cook until pasta is done, about 10 more minutes.
Remove Parmigiano rind (it will have melted mostly).
Season with salt and pepper, stir in fresh basil.
Serve with a drizzle of olive oil and grated Parmigiano.
cooking_tips: The Parmigiano rind adds umami depth - don't skip it.
Minestrone is better the next day after flavors meld.
Add leafy greens like spinach or kale in the last few minutes.
nutrition_benefits: Minestrone is rich in fiber from vegetables and beans. The variety of vegetables provides diverse vitamins and minerals. Beans add plant protein and iron.

short_description: Golden fried rice balls stuffed with ragu and mozzarella. These Sicilian street food favorites are named for their resemblance to small oranges.
steps: Cook rice in stock with saffron until done. Spread on tray to cool.
Mix cooled rice with 2 beaten eggs and Parmigiano.
Make filling: brown beef, add tomato sauce and peas, cook until thick.
Cut mozzarella into small cubes.
Take a handful of rice, form into a cup, add filling and mozzarella.
Close rice around filling to form a ball.
Beat remaining eggs. Dip balls in egg, then coat in breadcrumbs.
Heat oil to 350°F. Fry arancini until deep golden, about 4 minutes.
Drain on paper towels.
Serve hot with marinara sauce for dipping.
cooking_tips: The rice must be completely cool before shaping.
Wet hands help prevent sticking when forming balls.
Can be made ahead and reheated in the oven.
nutrition_benefits: Arancini provide protein from beef and cheese. Saffron contains antioxidants. The dish offers carbohydrates for energy and calcium from cheese.

short_description: The ultimate Roman pasta with just three ingredients: pasta, Pecorino Romano, and black pepper. This deceptively simple dish requires perfect technique to achieve its creamy, peppery glory.
steps: Toast peppercorns in a dry pan, then crack coarsely.
Finely grate the Pecorino Romano.
Cook pasta in well-salted water until al dente.
Reserve 2 cups pasta water before draining.
Toast cracked pepper in a large pan.
Add a ladle of pasta water to the pepper.
Add drained pasta to the pan.
Remove from heat, add cheese gradually while tossing.
Add pasta water as needed for creamy consistency.
Serve immediately with extra cheese and pepper.
cooking_tips: Work quickly off the heat to prevent clumping.
The starchy pasta water is essential for the sauce.
Use freshly cracked pepper, not pre-ground.
nutrition_benefits: Pecorino provides calcium and protein. Simple ingredients in perfect balance. A satisfying, quick meal.

short_description: A spicy tomato sauce with crispy guanciale and Pecorino Romano, tossed with bucatini pasta. This beloved Roman dish hails from the town of Amatrice.
steps: Cut guanciale into small strips.
Cook guanciale in a cold pan over medium heat until crispy.
Remove guanciale, leave the fat in the pan.
Add chili flakes to the fat briefly.
Add wine and let it evaporate.
Add crushed tomatoes and simmer 15 minutes.
Cook bucatini until al dente.
Add pasta to sauce with a splash of pasta water.
Toss with guanciale and grated Pecorino.
Serve with extra cheese on top.
cooking_tips: Authentic amatriciana never has onion.
The guanciale should be crispy.
Bucatini's hollow center captures the sauce perfectly.
nutrition_benefits: Tomatoes provide lycopene. Protein from guanciale and cheese. A hearty, satisfying meal.

short_description: Tender veal escalopes topped with sage and prosciutto, pan-fried and finished with a white wine butter sauce. The name means 'jumps in the mouth' for good reason.
steps: Pound veal escalopes thin between plastic wrap.
Place a sage leaf on each escalope.
Top with a slice of prosciutto, press to adhere.
Secure with a toothpick if needed.
Dust lightly with flour on both sides.
Heat butter and oil in a pan.
Cook veal prosciutto-side down first, 2 minutes.
Flip and cook 2 more minutes.
Remove veal, add wine to deglaze.
Swirl in more butter, pour sauce over veal.
cooking_tips: Don't overcook - veal should be tender.
The prosciutto crisps slightly in the pan.
Work in batches to avoid crowding.
nutrition_benefits: Lean protein from veal. Sage has antimicrobial properties. Quick-cooking preserves nutrients.

short_description: Fresh mozzarella, ripe tomatoes, and basil drizzled with olive oil. This iconic Capri salad showcases Italian simplicity and the importance of quality ingredients.
steps: Slice tomatoes and mozzarella into thick rounds.
Arrange alternating on a platter.
Tuck basil leaves between slices.
Season with flaky salt and pepper.
Drizzle generously with olive oil.
Let sit 10 minutes to develop flavors.
Serve at room temperature.
cooking_tips: Use the ripest tomatoes you can find.
Buffalo mozzarella is traditional, but fior di latte works too.
Quality olive oil is essential.
nutrition_benefits: Fresh mozzarella provides calcium. Tomatoes add lycopene. Olive oil offers heart-healthy fats.

short_description: Pillowy potato dumplings that melt in your mouth. These light, fluffy gnocchi are traditionally served with butter and sage or tomato sauce.
steps: Bake potatoes until tender, about 1 hour.
While hot, scoop flesh and rice or mash thoroughly.
Spread on counter to cool and dry slightly.
Add egg and salt, then flour gradually.
Knead gently until smooth dough forms.
Roll into ropes, cut into small pieces.
Roll each piece over fork tines for ridges.
Cook in boiling salted water until they float.
Brown butter with sage leaves.
Toss gnocchi with sage butter and Parmigiano.
cooking_tips: Use the minimum amount of flour needed.
Overworking makes gnocchi dense.
Baking potatoes keeps them drier than boiling.
nutrition_benefits: Potatoes provide potassium and vitamin C. Sage aids digestion. A comforting, satisfying meal.

short_description: Tender chicken cutlets in a bright lemon-caper butter sauce. This quick Italian-American classic is elegant enough for company yet simple for weeknights.
steps: Slice chicken breasts horizontally into thin cutlets.
Pound between plastic to even thickness.
Season and dredge in flour.
Heat oil and half the butter in a pan.
Cook chicken 3 minutes per side until golden.
Remove chicken and keep warm.
Add broth and lemon juice to pan.
Add capers and simmer to reduce slightly.
Swirl in remaining butter.
Pour sauce over chicken, garnish with parsley.
cooking_tips: Thin cutlets cook quickly and evenly.
Don't overcook - chicken should be juicy.
The sauce comes together in minutes.
nutrition_benefits: Lean protein from chicken. Lemon adds vitamin C. Capers provide antioxidants.

short_description: A hearty Tuscan bread soup thick with cannellini beans, cavolo nero, and vegetables. This peasant dish is even better when reheated the next day.
steps: Sauté onion, carrots, and celery in olive oil.
Add tomatoes and cook 10 minutes.
Add broth, beans, and rosemary.
Simmer for 30 minutes.
Remove stems from kale, chop leaves.
Add kale and cook until tender.
Tear bread into chunks.
Stir bread into soup, let it thicken.
Refrigerate overnight, then reheat (ribollita means reboiled).
Serve with generous drizzle of olive oil.
cooking_tips: Stale bread absorbs the broth perfectly.
The soup is meant to be very thick.
Always finish with excellent olive oil.
nutrition_benefits: Beans provide protein and fiber. Kale is nutrient-dense. A complete, nourishing meal.

short_description: Thin slices of cold poached veal draped with creamy tuna sauce. This elegant Piedmontese summer dish is a surprising and delicious combination.
steps: Poach veal with wine, vegetables, and bay leaves until tender.
Cool veal in the poaching liquid.
Blend tuna, anchovy, half the capers, and lemon juice.
Mix with mayonnaise until smooth.
Thin sauce with some poaching liquid if needed.
Slice cold veal very thin.
Arrange slices on a platter.
Cover with tuna sauce.
Garnish with remaining capers.
Refrigerate 1 hour before serving.
cooking_tips: The veal must be completely cold before slicing.
Sauce should coat the back of a spoon.
Can be made a day ahead.
nutrition_benefits: High in protein from veal and tuna. Omega-3 from tuna. A light, summery dish.

short_description: Fluffy, olive oil-rich flatbread with a crispy bottom and dimpled top. This Ligurian classic is perfect on its own or as the ultimate sandwich bread.
steps: Dissolve yeast and sugar in warm water.
Add flour and half the olive oil, mix until dough forms.
Knead 10 minutes until smooth and elastic.
Let rise in oiled bowl for 1 hour.
Oil a baking pan generously.
Stretch dough to fit pan.
Let rise another 30 minutes.
Dimple dough with fingertips.
Drizzle remaining oil, sprinkle salt and rosemary.
Bake at 425°F for 20-25 minutes until golden.
cooking_tips: Generous oil in the pan creates the crispy bottom.
Dimples hold pools of olive oil.
Best served warm the same day.
nutrition_benefits: Olive oil provides healthy fats. Rosemary has antioxidants. A satisfying bread with better fats than most.

short_description: Spaghetti tossed with golden garlic, olive oil, and chili flakes. This midnight pasta from Naples proves that simple ingredients, perfectly executed, create magic.
steps: Cook spaghetti in well-salted water until al dente.
Thinly slice the garlic.
Heat olive oil over medium-low heat.
Add garlic and cook until golden, not brown.
Add chili flakes.
Reserve pasta water, drain pasta.
Add pasta directly to the garlic oil.
Toss with some pasta water to emulsify.
Add chopped parsley.
Serve immediately.
cooking_tips: Don't burn the garlic - it turns bitter.
The pasta water creates a silky sauce.
Work quickly once pasta is drained.
nutrition_benefits: Garlic has antimicrobial properties. Olive oil provides healthy fats. A satisfying vegan option.

short_description: A silky, vanilla-scented cream pudding from Piedmont. This elegant dessert wobbles seductively and pairs perfectly with fresh berries or caramel.
steps: Soak gelatin in cold water until soft.
Split vanilla bean, scrape seeds.
Heat cream, milk, sugar, and vanilla until simmering.
Remove from heat.
Squeeze excess water from gelatin, add to cream.
Stir until dissolved.
Divide among ramekins or molds.
Refrigerate at least 4 hours until set.
Unmold onto plates or serve in glasses.
Top with fresh berries.
cooking_tips: The perfect panna cotta barely holds its shape.
Use less gelatin for softer set.
Dip molds briefly in hot water to unmold.
nutrition_benefits: Cream provides calcium. Berries add antioxidants and vitamin C. An indulgent treat.

short_description: A sweet and sour Sicilian eggplant dish with tomatoes, capers, and olives. This agrodolce vegetable medley is perfect as an appetizer or side dish.
steps: Cube eggplant, salt and drain for 30 minutes.
Fry eggplant in olive oil until golden, drain.
Sauté celery and onion until soft.
Add chopped tomatoes and cook 15 minutes.
Add capers, olives, vinegar, and sugar.
Simmer until sauce thickens.
Add fried eggplant and mix gently.
Toast pine nuts and stir in.
Let cool to room temperature.
Serve at room temperature with crusty bread.
cooking_tips: Salting removes bitterness from eggplant.
Caponata improves after a day in the fridge.
Balance sweet and sour to your taste.
nutrition_benefits: Eggplant is low in calories. Olive oil provides healthy fats. Capers add antioxidants.

short_description: The authentic slow-simmered meat sauce from Bologna, nothing like quick imitations. This rich, complex ragù takes hours but rewards with depth of flavor.
steps: Finely dice onion, carrot, and celery (soffritto).
Dice pancetta and render in a heavy pot.
Add soffritto and cook until soft.
Add meats and brown, breaking up well.
Add wine and cook until evaporated.
Add tomato paste and stir well.
Add milk and simmer until absorbed.
Add broth, cover and simmer 3-4 hours.
Stir occasionally, adding liquid if needed.
Serve with fresh tagliatelle and Parmigiano.
cooking_tips: Low and slow is essential for authentic ragù.
Milk tenderizes the meat and adds richness.
Traditional pairing is tagliatelle, not spaghetti.
nutrition_benefits: High in protein. The slow cooking develops complex flavors. A satisfying, hearty sauce.

short_description: A shot of hot espresso 'drowning' a scoop of cold vanilla gelato. This simple Italian dessert-meets-coffee is the perfect ending to any meal.
steps: Place scoops of gelato in chilled glasses or cups.
Pull fresh shots of espresso.
Pour hot espresso over the cold gelato.
Add a splash of amaretto if desired.
Serve immediately with a small spoon.
Enjoy as the gelato melts into the coffee.
cooking_tips: Use the best quality gelato you can find.
The espresso must be freshly pulled.
Serve immediately - timing is everything.
nutrition_benefits: Coffee provides antioxidants. Gelato offers calcium. A quick, satisfying dessert.

short_description: A golden platter of lightly battered and fried seafood. This Italian coastal classic features whatever is freshest, from calamari to shrimp to small fish.
steps: Clean and prepare all seafood, pat dry.
Mix flour and semolina for dredging.
Make light batter with some flour and sparkling water.
Heat oil to 350°F.
Dredge small pieces in flour mixture only.
Dip larger pieces in batter.
Fry in batches until golden and crispy.
Drain on paper towels.
Season immediately with salt.
Serve hot with lemon wedges.
cooking_tips: Keep seafood very cold until frying.
Don't overcrowd the oil.
Serve immediately - fritto misto waits for no one.
nutrition_benefits: Seafood provides lean protein and omega-3s. A festive treat best enjoyed occasionally.

short_description: Hunter-style braised chicken with tomatoes, wine, and herbs. This rustic Italian classic fills the kitchen with irresistible aromas as it simmers.
steps: Season chicken pieces with salt and pepper.
Brown chicken in olive oil on all sides.
Remove chicken, add onion and peppers.
Cook until softened, add garlic.
Add mushrooms and cook 5 minutes.
Pour in wine and reduce by half.
Add tomatoes, rosemary, and olives.
Return chicken to pot, nestling in sauce.
Cover and simmer 45 minutes until tender.
Serve with crusty bread or polenta.
cooking_tips: Bone-in, skin-on chicken has the most flavor.
The sauce should coat the chicken.
Even better reheated the next day.
nutrition_benefits: Protein from chicken. Tomatoes provide lycopene. Mushrooms add B vitamins.

short_description: Crispy fried pastry tubes filled with sweet ricotta cream and studded with chocolate or pistachios. These Sicilian classics are a beloved Italian-American treasure.
steps: Make dough with flour, butter, egg, Marsala, and sugar.
Knead until smooth, refrigerate 1 hour.
Drain ricotta overnight for thick consistency.
Mix ricotta with powdered sugar and vanilla.
Fold in chocolate chips.
Roll dough thin and cut circles.
Wrap around cannoli forms.
Seal with egg white.
Fry until golden and blistered.
Fill shells just before serving.
cooking_tips: Never fill cannoli ahead - shells get soggy.
Strain ricotta well for proper texture.
Dip ends in pistachios or chocolate.
nutrition_benefits: Ricotta provides calcium and protein. Pistachios add healthy fats. A celebratory treat.

short_description: Grilled eggplant slices rolled around ricotta and baked in tomato sauce. These vegetarian bundles are as beautiful as they are delicious.
steps: Slice eggplant lengthwise into thin strips.
Brush with oil and grill or broil until pliable.
Mix ricotta with Parmigiano, egg, and basil.
Season with salt and pepper.
Spread filling on each eggplant strip.
Roll up and place seam-side down.
Spread tomato sauce in baking dish.
Arrange rolls on sauce.
Top with mozzarella slices.
Bake at 375°F for 25 minutes until bubbly.
cooking_tips: Don't overfill or rolls will burst.
Eggplant should be flexible, not crispy.
Can be assembled ahead and baked later.
nutrition_benefits: Eggplant is low in calories. Ricotta provides protein and calcium. A satisfying vegetarian main.

short_description: A bone-in veal chop breaded and fried to golden perfection. This Milanese icon is the original schnitzel, served with just a wedge of lemon.
steps: Pound veal chops to even thickness, leaving bone attached.
Season with salt.
Beat eggs in a shallow bowl.
Put breadcrumbs on a plate.
Dip veal in egg, then breadcrumbs, pressing well.
Heat butter and oil in a large pan.
Fry cutlets until golden, about 4 minutes per side.
The coating should be crispy, meat just cooked through.
Drain briefly on paper towels.
Serve immediately with lemon wedges.
cooking_tips: The bone is traditional and adds flavor.
Use clarified butter to prevent burning.
Serve immediately - the coating gets soggy if left.
nutrition_benefits: Veal provides lean protein and iron. A rich dish best enjoyed on special occasions.

short_description: A light, foamy Italian custard made by whisking egg yolks with sugar and Marsala wine over gentle heat. This elegant Piedmontese dessert is heaven in a glass.
steps: Set up a double boiler with simmering water.
Whisk egg yolks and sugar until pale and thick.
Place bowl over simmering water.
Add Marsala gradually while whisking.
Whisk constantly for 8-10 minutes.
The mixture should triple in volume.
It's ready when it forms soft mounds.
Pour into glasses immediately.
Serve warm with fresh berries.
Can also be chilled for cold zabaglione.
cooking_tips: Water should not touch the bowl.
Never stop whisking or eggs will scramble.
Serve immediately for best foam.
nutrition_benefits: Eggs provide protein and choline. Berries add antioxidants. A light, elegant dessert.
